STEP 2 - EVIDENCE-BASED TREATMENT SELECTION: Now I'll select treatments based on current clinical guidelines. - First-line treatment per guidelines: Pharmacologic control of catecholamine excess (e.g., alpha-adrenergic blockade), management of underlying condition (e.g., hyperthyroidism treatment or tumor removal). - Supporting evidence: Alpha-blockade reduces adrenergic symptoms effectively in pheochromocytoma; beta-blockers may be added after alpha-blockade to control tachycardia. - Patient-specific considerations: Her episodes are frequent; her underlying condition (mast cell leukemia) may influence medication choices due to increased risk of hypersensitivity reactions. - Contraindications or cautions: Avoid unopposed beta-blockade in catecholamine excess without prior alpha-blockade; monitor for hypotension and tachycardia; consider possible interactions with her hematologic condition.  STEP 3 - PHARMACOLOGICAL INTERVENTIONS: If medications are appropriate, I'll select based on efficacy and safety. - Primary medication choice: Initiate alpha-adrenergic blockade with phenoxybenzamine, starting at 10 mg twice daily, titrated to control blood pressure and symptoms; consider other alpha-blockers like doxazosin if phenoxybenzamine is unavailable. - Rationale for selection: Phenoxybenzamine provides non-selective, irreversible alpha-blockade proven in pheochromocytoma management. - Expected timeline for improvement: Symptom relief within days to one week as blockade is titrated. - Key side effects to monitor: Hypotension, nasal congestion, orthostatic dizziness; closely monitor blood pressure during titration. - Alternative medications if first-line fails: If contraindicated or not tolerated, consider metyrosine or calcium channel blockers as adjuncts. STEP 5 - MONITORING & FOLLOW-UP STRATEGY: I'll establish appropriate monitoring and follow-up care. - Follow-up timeline: Reassess in 1-2 weeks to evaluate symptom control and medication tolerability; then every 4-6 weeks as clinically indicated. - Monitoring parameters: Symptom frequency and severity, blood pressure trends, side effects, and laboratory assessments (if relevant for underlying condition management). - Red flag symptoms: Persistent chest pain, severe hypertension, neurological changes, or signs of hypertensive crisis warrant immediate care. - Treatment response assessment: Reduction in episode frequency/intensity, stabilization of blood pressure, and improved sleep and fatigue.
